channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: The divorce between the U.S. and WHO is final this week. Or is it?
item.description: The U.S. is the only country allowed to withdraw from the World Health Organization. And Jan. 22 is the day when Trump's pullout announcement should go into effect. But ... it's complicated.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. is the only country allowed to withdraw from the World Health Organization. And Jan. 22 is the day when Trump's pullout announcement should go into effect. But ... it's complicated.

(Image credit: Fabrice Coffrini/AFP)
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Emanuel

item.title: Trump leaks world leaders' messages. And, Indiana wins its first national title
item.description: President Trump explains why he wants to acquire Greenland in private messages with world leaders. And, Indiana caps off a perfect football season with a national championship win over Miami.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump explains why he wants to acquire Greenland in private messages with world leaders. And, Indiana caps off a perfect football season with a national championship win over Miami.

(Image credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Trump's Board of Peace has several invited leaders trying to figure out how it'll work
item.description: It's unclear how many leaders have been asked to join the board, and the large number of invitations being sent out, including to countries that don't get along, has raised questions about the board's mandate and decision-making processes.
item.content:encoded:
It's unclear how many leaders have been asked to join the board, and the large number of invitations being sent out, including to countries that don't get along, has raised questions about the board's mandate and decision-making processes.

(Image credit: Mahmoud Illean)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Researchers find Antarctic penguin breeding is heating up sooner
item.description: Warming temperatures are forcing Antarctic penguins to breed earlier and that's a big problem for two of the cute tuxedoed species that face extinction by the end of the century, a study said.
item.content:encoded:
Warming temperatures are forcing Antarctic penguins to breed earlier and that's a big problem for two of the cute tuxedoed species that face extinction by the end of the century, a study said.

(Image credit: Mark Baker)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: As Trump dismantles the existing world order, his version is still taking shape
item.description: In his second term, the president is embracing a foreign policy that breaks sharply from U.S. tradition. Both supporters and critics say he's upending a global system in place for 80 years.
item.content:encoded:
In his second term, the president is embracing a foreign policy that breaks sharply from U.S. tradition. Both supporters and critics say he's upending a global system in place for 80 years.

(Image credit: Ariana Cubillos)
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Medicaid has a new way to pay for costly sickle cell treatment: Only if it works
item.description: Medicaid is doing a novel payment system for the new, promising and expensive sickle cell treatment. It may become a model for all gene therapies being developed.
item.content:encoded:
Medicaid is doing a novel payment system for the new, promising and expensive sickle cell treatment. It may become a model for all gene therapies being developed.

(Image credit: Judd Demaline for KFF Health News)
item.dc:creator: Phil Galewitz

item.title: Trump promised to cut energy bills in half. One year later, has he delivered?
item.description: Cheap gasoline, yes. Drill, baby, drill? Not so much. And electricity bills are going up, not down.
item.content:encoded:
Cheap gasoline, yes. Drill, baby, drill? Not so much. And electricity bills are going up, not down.

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
item.dc:creator: Camila Domonoske

item.title: Polyester clothing has been causing a stir online. But how valid are the concerns?
item.description: There has been a lot of conversation on social media about the downsides of polyester. But are those downsides as bad as they're believed to be? Are there upsides?
item.content:encoded:
There has been a lot of conversation on social media about the downsides of polyester. But are those downsides as bad as they're believed to be? Are there upsides?

(Image credit: Leon Neal)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie

item.title: New Orleans brings back the house call, sending nurses to visit newborns and moms
item.description: Louisiana has long struggled with maternal and infant mortality. In New Orleans, free home visits by nurses help spot medical problems early. It's a reproductive health policy with bipartisan support.
item.content:encoded:
Louisiana has long struggled with maternal and infant mortality. In New Orleans, free home visits by nurses help spot medical problems early. It's a reproductive health policy with bipartisan support.

(Image credit: Rosemary Westwood)
item.dc:creator: Rosemary Westwood

item.title: Less personnel drama but still sky high turnover one year into Trump's new term
item.description: A large share of the departures so far this term were on the National Security Council staff.
item.content:encoded:
A large share of the departures so far this term were on the National Security Council staff.

(Image credit: MANDEL NGAN)
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith
